Properties.Tooltip: Implements or uses a mechanism for authorization
Data that the element processes, stores, produces, or receives
Sensitivity of the processed data
Data that the element processes, stores, produces, or receives
Sensitivity of the processed data
Data that the element processes, stores, produces, or receives
Sensitivity of the processed data
Data that the element processes, stores, produces, or receives
Sensitivity of the processed data
Data that the element processes, stores, produces, or receives
Sensitivity of the processed data
Data that the element processes, stores, produces, or receives
Sensitivity of the processed data
Implements or uses a custom communication protocol
By default, processed data and data sensitivity are referenced from sender. Overwrite to set them manually
Data that the element processes, stores, produces, or receives
Sensitivity of the processed data
List of protocols used within the communication
Use either the properties derived from the protocols or define them manually
Data that the element processes, stores, produces, or receives
Sensitivity of the processed data
Authentication is always required before performing any functionality
Has True Random Number Generator (RNG)
Password hash is calculated of the joining of password and salt
Supports HID (Human Interface Device) class, which is, for example, used for keyboard and mouse
Supports mass storage class, which is, for example, used for storing files

stencilTypes.Name: RF Module
stencilTypes.Description: Proprietary protocols, e.g. protocols that use the 860 MHz band

Properties.Tooltip: Supports Wi-Fi Protected Setup (WPS)
Uses the Wi-Fi Protected Access 3 protocol
At the time of writing, it is advised to use at least Bluetooh BR/EDR version 4.1 or Bluetooth LE version 4.2
Secure modes are numeric comparison, passkey entry and out of band. Just works is not secure.
There are four security levels. The highest level, Security Level 4, should be used.
Users can log in to the system, usually by entering username and password.
Has Electronic Product Code (EPC)

Letters.Name: Spoofing
Letters.Description: Threat against the security goal authenticity

Letters.Name: Tampering
Letters.Description: Threat against the security goal integrity

Letters.Name: Repudiation
Letters.Description: Threat against the security goal Non-repudiation

Letters.Name: Information Disclosure
Letters.Description: Threat against the security goal confidentiality

Letters.Name: Denial of Service
Letters.Description: Threat against the security goal availability

Letters.Name: Elevation of Privilege
Letters.Description: Threat against the security goal authorization

Letters.Name: Linkability
Letters.Description: An adversary is able to link two items of interest without knowing the identity of the data subject(s) involved.

Letters.Name: Identifiability
Letters.Description: An adversary is able to identify a data subject from a set of data subjects through an item of interest.  ​

Letters.Name: Non-Repudiation
Letters.Description: The data subject is unable to deny a claim (e.g., having performed an action, or sent a request).

Letters.Name: Detectability
Letters.Description: An adversary is able to distinguish whether an item of interest about a data subject exists or not, regardless of being able to read the contents itself.

Letters.Name: Disclosure of Information
Letters.Description: An adversary is able to learn the content of an item of interest about a data subject.

Letters.Name: Unawareness
Letters.Description: The data subject is unaware of the collection, processing, storage, or sharing activities (and corresponding purposes) of the data subject’s personal data.

Letters.Name: Non-Compliance
Letters.Description: The processing, storage, or handling of personal data is not compliant with legislation, regulation, and/or policy.

Letters.Name: Safety
Letters.Description: Threats threatening the safety of operation, humans, and machines

Properties.Tooltip: Does the operating system only include components (libraries, modules, packages, ...) that are required to support the function of the device?
Is the OS the latest available stable version?
Does the device ship with the most secure configuration in place (security by default)?
Is there a process to update OS components to the latest stable version throughout the lifetime of a deployed device?
Are all ports, protocols, and services that are not used deactivated?
Is the access to the root file system restricted for users/applications?
Have all files and directories the minimum required access rights (least privilege principal)?
Is the file system encrypted?

myComponentSWTypes.Name: Trusted Computing Base
myComponentSWTypes.Description:
See section C and M of https://www.iotsecurityfoundation.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Best-Practice-Guides-Release-2_Digitalv3.pdf
and section 6.1 of https://www.gsma.com/iot/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/CLP.13-v2.2-GSMA-IoT-Security-Guidelines-for-Endpoint-Ecosystems.pdf

Properties.Tooltip: Does the device implement a secure boot?
Does the device has a immutable Root Of Trust in hardware?
Does the device boot the next stage only after the successful boot of the previous stage?
Is code checked for validity and trust immediately before running the code (to reduce Time of Check to Time of Use attacks)?

Properties.DisplayName: Has Boot Code Protection in RAM

Properties.Tooltip: Does the Trusted Computing Base utilize a Trusted Execution Environment for isolation of critical operations?
Are cryptographic operations (encryption, message signing, key exchange, key storage) performed by the Trusted Computing Base?
Does the update routine cryptographically validate the integrity of a software update package before the installation begins?
Does the update routine cryptographically validate the authenticity of a software update package before the installation begins?
Does the system ensure that the package cannot be modified or replaced by an attacker between being validated and installed - a TOCTOU (Time of Check to Time of Use) attack?
Does the system implement a fail safe mechanism that will leave the system in a known safe state in the event of a failed update?
Is the firmware update encrypted?
Is Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) implemented whenever possible/required?
Does an authentication response contain information which requirement is not fulfilled (e.g. password/username is wrong)?
Can unhandled exceptions occur?
Do error messages reveal details about the internal state (e.g. stack information, path, passwords)?

Properties.DisplayName: Device Has Tamper Resistant Unique ID
Properties.Tooltip: Is the device uniquely identifiable (the ID is factory-set and tamper resistant stored in hardware)?
Is the access for device management secured (unique password/certificate, MFA, etc.)?
Are users identified by a unique identifier?
Is it possible to assign different privileges to users?
Are passwords stored properly (using a cryptographic hash function along with a unique unpredictable salt)?
Does a factory reset remove all user data/credentials stored on the device?
Do all logged data comply with prevailing data protection regulations?
Is access to log files restricted to the minimum required rights to function properly?
Is there a maximum size for logs and is log rotating implemented?
Are logs regularly monitored and analyzed to extract valuable information and insight?
Are logs stored in their own partition, separate from other system files?
Does the device securely send logs to a central repository?
Does the device log passwords?
Are authentication attempts logged?
Are user login, logout, and inactivity logged?
Are changes to the firmware logged?
Are user management changes logged?
Are privilege changes logged?
Are configuration changes logged?

Properties.DisplayName: Warns User of Full Log File
Properties.Tooltip: Are users notified when the log file reaches its maximum size?
Does the system provide the ability to synchronize the system time?
Are only messages on port 8883 sent (MQTT over TLS)?
Is the client authenticated and authorized using its own X.509 certificate?
Is the security mode 'Sign' or 'SignAndEncrypt'?
Are all users authenticated (identifier 'anonymous' is not allowed)?
Is a strong security policy chosen that uses strong cryptographic algorithms?
Are only connections accepted that provide a trusted certificate?
Does the sever use secure protocols?
Does the server use at least TLS 1.2 and older versions of SSL/TLS are disabled?
Has the server a version banner?
Is the sever regular updated and patched?
Does the system deploy a web application firewall (WAF)?
Are all API calls monitored for potential API misuse?
Is the service running with root privileges?
Does the application operate at the lowest privilege level that is possible, with access only to resources needed (least privilege principal)?
Is the application isolated from others, e.g. using sandboxing techniques such as virtual machines, containerisation, or hardware mechansims?
Is all data input sanitized and validated before processing?
Are the hidden interfaces that developers created with the intend to be not publicly available?
Are keys stored in a cryptographic vault, such as a trusted platform module (TPM), secure element (SE), or hardware security module (HSM)?
Are cryptographic operations (such as key access, encryption, and signing) executed in a trusted environment (e.g. separate module)?
Are keys encrypted using a key encryption key (KEK)?
Is the entire certificate chain validated before trusting a certificate?
Is there a secure and reliable way to update certificates?
Is it possible to revoke a certificate / check a certificate against a revocation list?

myComponentPTypes.Name: Incident Response
myComponentPTypes.Description: See IoT Security Foundation: Vulnerability Disclosure

Properties.Tooltip: Does the manufacturer enable a coordinated vulnerability disclosure?
Is there a bug bounty program?
Is there information on the timelines for acknowledgement and resolution of reported issues?
Is there a incident response team within the organization?
Is there a publicly available date for the end of support?
Is a rough update interval publicly available for customers?
If updates are not applied automatically: is there a process for notifying customers about a new update?
Are penetration tests regularly (at least annually) performed?
Are audits regularly performed by external institutes?
Is there a public vulnerability reporting system?
Does the website of the manufacturer use /security to provide security-related topics?
Does the website of the manufacturer provide a security.txt including all security-related sites and contact information?
Does the manufacturer provide an email account for security related topics?
Is there are publicly available vulnerability disclosure policy?
Does the manufacturer provide a PGP on their website for secure communication?
Is a privacy impact assessment conducted?
Is the privacy impact assessment regularly updated (e.g. annually)?
Are appropriate technical and operational measures (e. g. data pseudoymisation, data minimisation) implemented?
Does the system comply with all privacy laws that govern user control over their personal data?
Does the system implement appropriate technical and operational measures for the protection of users rights and freedoms (e. g. transparent information, right of access, right to erasure)?
Are users sufficiently aware what personal data is being exposed to the manufacturer, operator, and other partner organisations?
Does the system implement an opt-int mechanism to get explicit user consent for personal data processing?

myComponentPTypes.Name: Safety Impact Assessment
myComponentPTypes.Description: Evaluate the safety impacts of an IoT system, log all safety risks, prioritize the risks, and implement mitigations for each risk. Incorporate device and environmental controls to enforce safety requirements, as necessary.

Properties.Tooltip: Is a safety impact assessment conducted?
Is a fault tree analysis conducted?
Is there a regular audit of the account management (user, administrator, etc.)?
Is certificate-based authentication used to access the system?
Is the lifetime of operational certificates no longer than 3 years?
Is there a process for certificate revocation?
Is there a certificate management policy (creation, processing, storage, etc.)?
Is there an automated process to renew certificates?
Is there a established supply chain risk management program?
Are third party components (hardware, software) tracked, monitored, and regularly updated?
Is a Secure Development Plan (SDL) implemented (e.g. based on ISO/IEC 27034)?

Properties.DisplayName: Has Responsible Person For Reg. Compliance
Properties.Tooltip: Do you have a group and organization responsible for regulatory compliance of security, privacy and data protection, and safety?

Properties.DisplayName: Has Responsible Person For Security Compliance
Properties.Tooltip: Do you have a group responsible for security compliance and quality control?
Do you have a responsible group for auditing?
Does your SDL program include internal functional and security testing of the system?
Is there a holistic security training and awareness program for employees?
Is there a continuous, regular and frequently security training for employees?
Are secure coding guidelines implemented?

threatActors.Name: Cyber criminals
Motive: Blackmail the victim to get money

threatCategories.Name: Misuse of computing power
threatCategories.Description: Starting DDoS attacks; Sending spam mails; Mining of crypto currencies

threatCategories.Name: Misuse of electrical power
threatCategories.Description: Charging the phone; Rewiring to other equipment

threatCategories.Name: Code/Data tampering/poisoning
threatCategories.Description: Manipulating the system in order to make it work (slightly) different

threatCategories.Name: Denial of service
threatCategories.Description: Putting the system in a state in which it can't fulfill it's service (e.g., setting invalid configurations, flooding with network requests)

threatCategories.Name: Information disclosure/leaking
threatCategories.Description: Extracting (secret) information to unauthorized users

threatCategories.Name: Privilege abuse
threatCategories.Description: Reading data/logs to monitor other users; Using insider knowledge for personal gain (e.g., stock trading)

threatCategories.Name: Repudiation of actions
threatCategories.Description: Denying performed actions or usage of the system

threatCategories.Name: Environmental conditions
threatCategories.Description: ToDo: Corrosion, Frostiness, Heat/Fire, Mechanical stress, Over-voltage, Low-voltage, Water, Moisture, Pollution

threatCategories.Name: Identification
threatCategories.Description:
Identification denotes the threat of associating a (persistent) identifier, e.g. a name and address or a pseudonym of any kind, with an individual and data about him.
-- Ziegeldorf et. al, Privacy in the Internet of Things: Threats and Challenges

threatCategories.Name: Inventory attacks
threatCategories.Description:
Inventory attacks refer to the unauthorized collection of information about the existence and characteristics of personal things.
-- Ziegeldorf et. al, Privacy in the Internet of Things: Threats and Challenges

threatCategories.Name: Lifecycle transitions
threatCategories.Description:
Privacy is threatened when smart things disclose private information during changes of control spheres in their lifecycle.
-- Ziegeldorf et. al, Privacy in the Internet of Things: Threats and Challenges

threatCategories.Name: Linkage
threatCategories.Description:
This threat consists in linking different previously separated systems such that the combination of data sources reveals (truthful or erroneous) information that the subject did not disclose to the previously isolated sources and, most importantly, also did not want to reveal.
-- Ziegeldorf et. al, Privacy in the Internet of Things: Threats and Challenges

threatCategories.Name: Localization and tracking
threatCategories.Description:
Localization and tracking is the threat of determining and recording a person’s location through time and space.
-- Ziegeldorf et. al, Privacy in the Internet of Things: Threats and Challenges

threatCategories.Name: Privacy-violating interaction and presentation
threatCategories.Description:
This threat refers to conveying private information through a public medium and in the process disclosing it to an unwanted audience. It can be loosely sketched as shoulder- surfing but in real-world environments.
-- Ziegeldorf et. al, Privacy in the Internet of Things: Threats and Challenges

threatCategories.Name: Profiling
threatCategories.Description:
Profiling denotes the threat of compiling information dossiers about individuals in order to infer interests by correlation with other profiles and data.
-- Ziegeldorf et. al, Privacy in the Internet of Things: Threats and Challenges

threatCategories.Name: Linkability
threatCategories.Description: An adversary is able to link two items of interest without knowing the identity of the data subject(s) involved.

threatCategories.Name: Identifiability
threatCategories.Description: An adversary is able to identify a data subject from a set of data subjects through an item of interest.  ​

threatCategories.Name: Non-Repudiation
threatCategories.Description: The data subject is unable to deny a claim (e.g., having performed an action, or sent a request).

threatCategories.Name: Detectability
threatCategories.Description: An adversary is able to distinguish whether an item of interest about a data subject exists or not, regardless of being able to read the contents itself.

threatCategories.Name: Disclosure of Information
threatCategories.Description: An adversary is able to learn the content of an item of interest about a data subject.

threatCategories.Name: Unawareness
threatCategories.Description: The data subject is unaware of the collection, processing, storage, or sharing activities (and corresponding purposes) of the data subject’s personal data.

threatCategories.Name: Non-Compliance
threatCategories.Description: The processing, storage, or handling of personal data is not compliant with legislation, regulation, and/or policy.

threatCategories.Name: Safety
threatCategories.Description: Threats threatening the safety of operation, humans, and machines

threatCategories.Name: Privacy
threatCategories.Description: Threats threatening the privacy

attackVectors.Name: Insufficient random values
attackVectors.Description: Use of insufficiently random values

attackVectors.Name: Reverse engineering/Cloning
attackVectors.Description: Extracting the PCB design to understand or clone the product; e.g., by CAD file theft or modern reverse engineering techniques

attackVectors.Name: Hardware trojan
attackVectors.Description: Malicious design modification / insertion of a hardware Trojan
attackVectors.Adversaries: Untrusted foundry, untrusted IP vendor, untrusted CAD tool, untrusted design facilities

attackVectors.Name: Sensitive information uncleared
attackVectors.Description: Sensitive information in memory (SRAM) must be cleared when the system performs a power or debug state transition. For example, SRAMs keep their data after a software reset.

attackVectors.Name: Boot code protection
attackVectors.Description: Manipulation of boot code in volatile memory to bypass secure boot.

attackVectors.Name: Physical side channel attacks
attackVectors.Description: Physical side channels expose sensitive information due to patterns in physically observable phenomena such as variations in power consumption, electromagnetic emissions, or acoustic emissions.

attackVectors.Name: Firmware dumping
attackVectors.Description: Extracting the firmware via physical interfaces

attackVectors.Name: Firmware overwrite
attackVectors.Description: Overwriting the firmware via a physical interface

attackVectors.Name: Improper isolation of shared resoruces
attackVectors.Description: For example, a specific memory range is only accessible with higher privileges. However, the memory is mapped to another range with unrestricted access. See CWE for more examples.

attackVectors.Name: Improper certificate validation
attackVectors.Description: Missing or incorrect certificate validation, e.g. improper validation of chain of trust, expiration, revocation, etc.

attackVectors.Name: Replacement with malicious peripheral
attackVectors.Description: Alteration of PCB (processor, data store, interface controller, any IC) to bypass restrictions, access data, etc.

attackVectors.Name: Factory oversupply
attackVectors.Description: The contracted manufacturer produces more parts than specified and keeps/resells the surplus.

attackVectors.Name: Provisioning data cloning
attackVectors.Description: The contracted manufacturer clones data that was initially inserted (e.g., key material).

attackVectors.Name: Weak block cipher mode
attackVectors.Description: Deprecated block cipher modes, such as ECB or CBC, do not provide enough security.

attackVectors.Name: Firmware downgrade
attackVectors.Description: For practical reasons a downgrade is probably necessary, but security patches should not be reversible (e.g. by using special security version numbers).

attackVectors.Name: Permissive status display
attackVectors.Description: Details about status, configuration, software version, metadata, logging data, operation status, etc. are shown to unauthorized users

attackVectors.Name: Default password
attackVectors.Description: A common vulnerability are default credentials that can be found in the manual.

attackVectors.Name: Battery draining attack
attackVectors.Description: Denial of sleep, flooding attacks

attackVectors.Name: HID/Keyboard spoofing
attackVectors.Description: An USB stick imitates a keyboard to inject commands. The stick may be a present or found in the parking lot.

attackVectors.Name: USB Killer
attackVectors.Description: A device that looks similar to an USB flash drive creates high-voltage pulses to damage/destroy the hardware. This type of attack is also possible at other interfaces than USB as there are publicly available adapter for HDMI and Thunderbolt, for example.

attackVectors.Name: Selective forwarding
attackVectors.Description: Selective forwarding of messages/network packets

attackVectors.Name: Password sharing
attackVectors.Description: Users/Employees share the password, e.g. using a note next to the device.

attackVectors.Name: Replay attack
attackVectors.Description: Replaying a capture network package

attackVectors.Name: Cross Site Scripting (XSS)
attackVectors.Description: See CWE-79 and CAPEC-63

attackVectors.Name: Unawareness
attackVectors.Description: The affected subject is not aware of the collection, processing, storage, or sharing of the subject's data.

threatQuestions.Name: Updatable
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device provide the ability to update or patch the firmware?

threatQuestions.Name: Risky cryptographic algorithm
threatQuestions.Description: No use of custom encryption schemes, deprecated algorithms (DES, MD5, SHA1, etc.)
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device use only secure, standardized, and approved cryptographic algorithms?

threatQuestions.Name: Improper access control
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device implement and correctly perform access control on physical debug/test interfaces to check users' authorization?

threatQuestions.Name: Internal assets exposed
threatQuestions.Question: [Has access control] Does the device, supporting multiple debug access levels, assign the right access level to internal assets?

threatQuestions.Name: Hardware Feature Restriction
threatQuestions.Description: Hardware functionality can be used to modify the memory or to observe physical side channels.
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device restrict access to software-controllable device functionality (e.g. power and clock management)?

threatQuestions.Name: Address Region Overlap
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device allow overlapping of address regions (possibly leading to bypassing of memory protection)?

threatQuestions.Name: State Transition
threatQuestions.Description: E.g., an uncleared SRAM can expose information after a software reset.
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device clear sensitive information when a power or debug state transition is performed?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing secure boot
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device implement a secure boot?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing immutable Root of Trust
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device has a immutable Root of Trust in hardware?

threatQuestions.Name: Improper boot order
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device boot the next stage only after the successful boot of the previous stage?

threatQuestions.Name: TOCTOU attack
threatQuestions.Question: Is code checked for validity and trust immediately before running the code (to reduce Time of Check to Time of Use attacks)?

threatQuestions.Name: Boot Code Protection in RAM
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device protect boot code (from ROM) during execution in a volatile memory?

threatQuestions.Name: Less-secure downgrade
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device's TLS version and configuration exclude less-secure algorithms?

threatQuestions.Name: Weak block cipher mode
threatQuestions.Description: Deprecated block cipher modes, such as ECB or CBC, do not provide enough security.
threatQuestions.Question: For symmetric algorithms using block ciphers, does the device use strong block cipher modes?

threatQuestions.Name: Appropriate parameters
threatQuestions.Description: For example, the encryption scheme may be good, but its parameters are not sufficient (AES-128 vs AES-256, ECC secp256 vs secp384).
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device use up-to-date and appropriate parameters for cryptographic primitives?

threatQuestions.Name: Sufficient entropy
threatQuestions.Description: A strong source of entropy could be a True Random Number Generator (TRNG), human input, etc?\nThe entropy is required for generating true random numbers or to use it as seed for a Cryptographically Secure RNG.
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device provide a strong source of entropy?

threatQuestions.Name: Nonce reuse
threatQuestions.Description: IVs and nonces that are required by many cryptographic algorithms must be used only once and must be generated with high entropy, which is usually ensured by a true random number generator.
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device use values for initialization vectors (IV) or nonces only once?

threatQuestions.Name: Roll-back
threatQuestions.Description: For practical reasons a downgrade is probably necessary, but security patches should not be reversible (e.g. by using special security version numbers).
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device prevent a firmware downgrade (roll-back) to vulnerable versions?

threatQuestions.Name: Hard-coded credentials
threatQuestions.Description: For example, does the software or hardware include fixed strings/keys for developer authentication (backdoor)?
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device use/contain hard-coded credentials?

threatQuestions.Name: Default credentials
threatQuestions.Description: A common vulnerability are default credentials that can be found in the manual.
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device ship with default credentials?

threatQuestions.Name: Password requirements
threatQuestions.Description: Requirements to length, reuse, common passwords, expiration, etc?
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device enforce requirements to passwords?

threatQuestions.Name: Multi-factor authentication
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device support multi-factor authentication?

threatQuestions.Name: Restriction of attempts
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device restrict failed authentication attempts within a short time frame?

threatQuestions.Name: Sensitive (authentication) information exposed
threatQuestions.Question: Does an authentication response contain information which requirement is not fulfilled (e.g. password/username is wrong)?

threatQuestions.Name: Session ID expiration
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device invalidate session identifiers (e.g. session ID) after a logout?

threatQuestions.Name: Session timeout
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device invalidate a session after a period of inactivity?

threatQuestions.Name: Password recovery
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device implement a strong mechanism for password recovery after users forgot it?

threatQuestions.Name: Client-side hashing
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device use a password hash instead of password for authentication (client-side password hashing)?

threatQuestions.Name: Hidden interfaces
threatQuestions.Question: Are the hidden interfaces that developers created with the intend to be not publicly available?

threatQuestions.Name: Integrity validation
threatQuestions.Question: Does the update routine cryptographically validate the integrity of a software update package before the installation begins?

threatQuestions.Name: Authenticity validation
threatQuestions.Question: Does the update routine cryptographically validate the authenticity of a software update package before the installation begins?

threatQuestions.Name: TOCTOU attack
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device ensure that the package cannot be modified or replaced by an attacker between being validated and installed - a TOCTOU (Time of Check to Time of Use) attack?

threatQuestions.Name: Unknown state
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device implement a fail safe mechanism that will leave the system in a known safe state in the event of a failed update?

threatQuestions.Name: Improper log access control
threatQuestions.Question: Is access to log files restricted to the minimum required rights to function properly?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing separate location for log files
threatQuestions.Question: Are logs stored in their own partition, separate from other system files?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing log rotation
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a maximum size for logs and is log rotating implemented?

threatQuestions.Name: Log file overwritten
threatQuestions.Question: Are users notified when the log file reaches its maximum size?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing log evaluation
threatQuestions.Question: Are logs regularly monitored and analyzed to extract valuable information and insight?

threatQuestions.Name: Regulation compliance
threatQuestions.Question: Do all logged data comply with prevailing data protection regulations?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing central log backup
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device securely send logs to a central repository?

threatQuestions.Name: Log files contain passwords
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device log passwords?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing log entry
threatQuestions.Question: Are authentication attempts logged?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing log entry
threatQuestions.Question: Are user login, logout, and inactivity logged?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing log entry
threatQuestions.Question: Are privilege changes logged?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing log entry
threatQuestions.Question: Are user management changes logged?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing log entry
threatQuestions.Question: Are changes to the firmware logged?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing public policy
threatQuestions.Description: The policy can be provided either in-house or through a third party.
threatQuestions.Question: Is there are publicly available vulnerability disclosure policy?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing /security page
threatQuestions.Question: Does the website of the manufacturer use /security to provide security-related topics?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing security.txt
threatQuestions.Question: Does the website of the manufacturer provide a security.txt including all security-related sites and contact information?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing contact email address
threatQuestions.Question: Does the manufacturer provide an email account for security related topics?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing PGP key
threatQuestions.Question: Does the manufacturer provide a PGP on their website for secure communication?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing reporting system
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a public vulnerability reporting system?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing timeline info
threatQuestions.Question: Is there information on the timelines for acknowledgement and resolution of reported issues?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing bug bounty program
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a bug bounty program?

threatQuestions.Name: Non-disclosure
threatQuestions.Question: Does the manufacturer enable a coordinated vulnerability disclosure?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing Firmware Encryption
threatQuestions.Question: Is the firmware update encrypted?

threatQuestions.Name: Unnecessary components
threatQuestions.Question: Does the operating system only include components (libraries, modules, packages, ...) that are required to support the function of the device?

threatQuestions.Name: Outdated OS version
threatQuestions.Question: Is the OS the latest available stable version?

threatQuestions.Name: Secure configuration not default
threatQuestions.Question: Does the device ship with the most secure configuration in place (security by default)?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing component update process
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a process to update OS components to the latest stable version throughout the lifetime of a deployed device?

threatQuestions.Name: Activated services and ports
threatQuestions.Question: Are all ports, protocols, and services that are not used deactivated?

threatQuestions.Name: Improper permission configuration
threatQuestions.Question: Is the access to the root file system restricted for users/applications?

threatQuestions.Name: Least privilege violation
threatQuestions.Question: Have all files and directories the minimum required access rights (least privilege principal)?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing file system encryption
threatQuestions.Question: Is the file system encrypted?

threatQuestions.Name: Least privilege violation
threatQuestions.Question: Does the application operate at the lowest privilege level that is possible, with access only to resources needed (least privilege principal)?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing application isolation
threatQuestions.Question: Is the application isolated from others, e.g. using sandboxing techniques such as virtual machines, containerisation, or hardware mechansims?

threatQuestions.Name: Improper input validation
threatQuestions.Question: Is all data input sanitized and validated before processing?

threatQuestions.Name: Keys not stored in security module
threatQuestions.Question: Are keys stored in a cryptographic vault, such as a trusted platform module (TPM), secure element (SE), or hardware security module (HSM)?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing key encryption
threatQuestions.Question: Are keys encrypted using a key encryption key (KEK)?

threatQuestions.Name: Key usage in untrusted environment
threatQuestions.Question: Are cryptographic operations (such as key access, encryption, and signing) executed in a trusted environment (e.g. separate module)?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing tamper resistant unique ID
threatQuestions.Question: Is the device uniquely identifiable (the ID is factory-set and tamper resistant stored in hardware)?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing unique user identification
threatQuestions.Question: Are users identified by a unique identifier?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing privilege differentiation
threatQuestions.Question: Is it possible to assign different privileges to users?

threatQuestions.Name: Improper password storage
threatQuestions.Question: Are passwords stored properly, i.e. using a cryptographic hash function (specifically for passwords) along with a unique unpredictable salt?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing certificate chain verification
threatQuestions.Question: Is the entire certificate chain validated before trusting a certificate?

threatQuestions.Name: Certificate expiration
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a secure and reliable way to update certificates?

threatQuestions.Name: Revoked certificate
threatQuestions.Question: Is it possible to revoke a certificate / check a certificate against a revocation list?

threatQuestions.Name: Uncleared user data
threatQuestions.Question: Does a factory reset remove all user data/credentials stored on the device?

threatQuestions.Name: Unhandled exceptions
threatQuestions.Question: Can unhandled exceptions occur?

threatQuestions.Name: Sensitive (error) information exposed
threatQuestions.Question: Do error messages reveal details about the internal state (e.g. stack information, path, passwords)?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing log entry
threatQuestions.Question: Are configuration changes logged?

threatQuestions.Name: Unsecure mode
threatQuestions.Question: Is the security mode 'Sign' or 'SignAndEncrypt'?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing user authentication
threatQuestions.Question: Are all users authenticated (identifier 'anonymous' is not allowed)?

threatQuestions.Name: Weak cryptographic algorithms
threatQuestions.Question: Is a strong security policy chosen that uses strong cryptographic algorithms?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing certificate
threatQuestions.Question: Are only connections accepted that provide a trusted certificate?

threatQuestions.Name: Unsecure protocols
threatQuestions.Question: Does the sever use secure protocols?

threatQuestions.Name: Unsecure SSL/TLS version
threatQuestions.Question: Does the server use at least TLS 1.2 and older versions of SSL/TLS are disabled?

threatQuestions.Name: Exposes server version
threatQuestions.Question: Has the server a version banner?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing patches
threatQuestions.Question: Is the sever regular updated and patched?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing web application firewall
threatQuestions.Question: Does the system deploy a web application firewall (WAF)?

threatQuestions.Name: Undetected misuse of API
threatQuestions.Question: Are all API calls monitored for potential API misuse?

threatQuestions.Name: Unsecure management access
threatQuestions.Question: Is the access for device management secured (unique password/certificate, MFA, etc.)?

threatQuestions.Name: Unsecure message
threatQuestions.Question: Are only messages on port 8883 sent (MQTT over TLS)?

threatQuestions.Name: Client spoofing
threatQuestions.Question: Is the client authenticated and authorized using its own X.509 certificate?

threatQuestions.Name: No privacy impact assessment
threatQuestions.Description: The PIA should address the following at minimum: identification of sensitive data stored on the device, mechanisms used to inform users of data collected; consent for data collection; processes for use and review of personal data before it is transferred, notice concerning the timing and frequency of data collection, and the ability for users to opt-in or out of data sharing.
threatQuestions.Question: Is a privacy impact assessment conducted?

threatQuestions.Name: Outdated privacy impact assessment
threatQuestions.Question: Is the privacy impact assessment regularly updated (e.g. annually)?

threatQuestions.Name: No safety impact assessment
threatQuestions.Description: Evaluate the safety impacts of an IoT system, log all safety risks, prioritize the risks, and implement mitigations for each risk. Incorporate device and environmental controls to enforce safety requirements, as necessary
threatQuestions.Question: Is a safety impact assessment conducted?

threatQuestions.Name: No fault tree analysis
threatQuestions.Description: Conduct fault tree analysis to identify and prioritize safety risks associated with the IoT system.
threatQuestions.Question: Is a fault tree analysis conducted?

threatQuestions.Name: No account management
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a regular audit of the account management (user, administrator, etc.)?

threatQuestions.Name: Weak authentication
threatQuestions.Question: Is certificate-based authentication used to access the system?

threatQuestions.Name: Root privileges
threatQuestions.Question: Is the service running with root privileges?

threatQuestions.Name: Certificates with long lifetime
threatQuestions.Description: Device certificates may be used without expiration. In this case, short-term operational certificates should be established.
threatQuestions.Question: Is the lifetime of operational certificates no longer than 3 years?

threatQuestions.Name: No revocation process
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a process for certificate revocation?

threatQuestions.Name: No management policy
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a certificate management policy (creation, processing, storage, etc.)?

threatQuestions.Name: No automated renewal process
threatQuestions.Question: Is there an automated process to renew certificates?

threatQuestions.Name: No incident response team
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a incident response team within the organization?

threatQuestions.Name: No supply chain risk management program
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a established supply chain risk management program?

threatQuestions.Name: Risks from third party components
threatQuestions.Question: Are third party components (hardware, software) tracked, monitored, and regularly updated?

threatQuestions.Name: No regular penetration tests
threatQuestions.Question: Are penetration tests regularly (at least annually) performed?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing privacy measures
threatQuestions.Question: Are appropriate technical and operational measures (e. g. data pseudoymisation, data minimisation) implemented?

threatQuestions.Name: Privacy law compliance
threatQuestions.Question: Does the system comply with all privacy laws that govern user control over their personal data?

threatQuestions.Name: User rights and freedoms violation
threatQuestions.Question: Does the system implement appropriate technical and operational measures for the protection of users rights and freedoms (e. g. transparent information, right of access, right to erasure)?

threatQuestions.Name: Insufficient user awareness
threatQuestions.Question: Are users sufficiently aware what personal data is being exposed to the manufacturer, operator, and other partner organisations?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing opt-in mechanism
threatQuestions.Question: Does the system implement an opt-int mechanism to get explicit user consent for personal data processing?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing SDL program
threatQuestions.Question: Is a Secure Development Plan (SDL) implemented (e.g. based on ISO/IEC 27034)?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing responsibility for regulatory compliance
threatQuestions.Question: Do you have a group and organization responsible for regulatory compliance of security, privacy and data protection, and safety?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing responsibility for security compliance
threatQuestions.Question: Do you have a group responsible for security compliance and quality control?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing responsibility for auditing
threatQuestions.Question: Do you have a responsible group for auditing?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing testing
threatQuestions.Question: Does your SDL program include internal functional and security testing of the system?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing trusted execution environment
threatQuestions.Question: Does the Trusted Computing Base utilize a Trusted Execution Environment for isolation of critical operations?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing isolation of cryptographic operations
threatQuestions.Question: Are cryptographic operations (encryption, message signing, key exchange, key storage) performed by the Trusted Computing Base?

threatQuestions.Name: Decryption of recorded traffic
threatQuestions.Question: Is Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) implemented whenever possible/required?

threatQuestions.Name: No external audit
threatQuestions.Question: Are audits regularly performed by external institutes?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing employee training and awareness
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a holistic security training and awareness program for employees?

threatQuestions.Name: No regular employee training
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a continuous, regular and frequently security training for employees?

threatQuestions.Name: No secure coding guidelines
threatQuestions.Description: Secure coding practices include, for example, input validation, output encoding, session management, and database security.
threatQuestions.Question: Are secure coding guidelines implemented?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing end of support date
threatQuestions.Question: Is there a publicly available date for the end of support?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing update interval information
threatQuestions.Question: Is a rough update interval publicly available for customers?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing update notification
threatQuestions.Question: If updates are not applied automatically: is there a process for notifying customers about a new update?

threatQuestions.Name: Missing time synchronization
threatQuestions.Question: Does the system provide the ability to synchronize the system time?

threatRuleGroups.Name: STRIDE per Interaction (old)
threatRuleGroups.Description: According to Adam Shostack: Threat Modeling - Designing for Security

threatRuleGroups.Name: STRIDE-per-Interaction
threatRuleGroups.Description: According to Adam Shostack: Threat Modeling - Designing for Security

threatRules.Name: Hardware trojan
threatRules.Description: ToDo

threatRules.Name: Process -> Data Store
threatRules.Description: Process has outbound data flow to data store.

threatRules.Name: Process -> Process
threatRules.Description: Process sends output to another process.

threatRules.Name: Process -> Ext. Entity
threatRules.Description: Process sends output to external entity (code).

threatRules.Name: Process -> Phy. Ext. Entity
threatRules.Description: Process sends output to external entity (human).

threatRules.Name: Process <- Data Store
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from a data store.

threatRules.Name: Process <- Process
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from a process.

threatRules.Name: Process <- Ext. Entity
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from a external entity.

threatRules.Name: Data Store <- Process
threatRules.Description: Process has outbound data flow to data store.

threatRules.Name: Data Store -> Process
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from data store.

threatRules.Name: Ext. Entity -> Process
threatRules.Description: External interactor passes input to process.

threatRules.Name: Ext. Entity <- Process
threatRules.Description: External interactor gets input from process.

threatRules.Name: FW Dumping
threatRules.Description: This enables IP theft and allows debugging of binaries to find further vulnerabilities that can be exploited

threatRules.Name: Improper user input validation
threatRules.Description: Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.

threatRules.Name: Blocking battery charging
threatRules.Description: For example, https://www.brokenwire.fail/

threatRules.Name: Cleartext storage on unencrypted physical storage
SQL Injection
threatRules.Description: SQL injection is an attack in which malicious code is inserted into strings that are later passed to an instance of SQL Server for parsing and execution. Any procedure that constructs SQL statements should be reviewed for injection vulnerabilities because SQL Server will execute all syntactically valid queries that it receives. Even parameterized data can be manipulated by a skilled and determined attacker.

threatRules.Name: Malicious file
threatRules.Description: Social engineering: An USB flash drive contains interesting but malicious files

threatRules.Name: USB killer
threatRules.Description: Note: this type of attack is also possible at other interfaces such as HDMI, Thunderbolt, etc.

threatRules.Name: Protocol design issues
threatRules.Description: Custom protocols may be not sufficiently tested and therefore more likely include vulnerabilities

threatRules.Name: Compliance loss duty cycle limit
threatRules.Description: For example Europe defines a maximum duty cycle

threatRules.Name: Privacy-violating interaction
threatRules.Description: Gestures in public environments result in privacy-violating interaction

threatRules.Name: Missing separate location for log files
Missing log entry
threatRules.Description: Missing security-relevant information for audits: login attempts, changes in user session, firmware updates, etc.

threatRules.Name: Non-disclosure
threatRules.Description: There are mainly coordinated vulnerability disclosure and non-disclosure. Coordinated vulnerability is important for independent security researchers to get reputation. Non-disclosure could possible lead to public reports without fixed vulnerabilities.

threatRules.Name: Missing security.txt
threatRules.Description:
https://securitytxt.org/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security.txt

threatRules.Name: Missing contact email address
threatRules.Description: E.g. security-alert, security, psirt, csirt@companydomain.com

threatRules.Name: Keys not stored in security module
Spoofing the sender process
threatRules.Description: The sender process may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to the receiver process. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source process.

threatRules.Name: Spoofing the receiver process
threatRules.Description: The receiver may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by the sender. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.

threatRules.Name: Spoofing the external entity
threatRules.Description: The external entity may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to the receiver process. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.

threatRules.Name: Spoofing of source data store
threatRules.Description: The data store may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to incorrect data delivered to the receiver. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the source data store.

threatRules.Name: Spoofing of destination data store
threatRules.Description: The data store may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being written to the attacker's target instead of the data store. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination data store.

threatRules.Name: Risks from logging
threatRules.Description: Log readers can come under attack via log files. Consider ways to canonicalize data in all logs. Implement a single reader for the logs, if possible, in order to reduce attack surface area. Be sure to understand and document log file elements which come from untrusted sources.

threatRules.Name: JSON Processing
threatRules.Description: If a dataflow contains JSON, JSON processing and hijacking threats may be exploited.

threatRules.Name: Lower trusted subject updates logs
threatRules.Description: If you have trust levels, is anyone other outside of the highest trust level allowed to log? Letting everyone write to your logs can lead to repudiation problems. Only allow trusted code to log.

threatRules.Name: Data logs from unknown source
threatRules.Description: If you have trust levels, is anyone other outside of the highest trust level allowed to log? Letting everyone write to your logs can lead to repudiation problems. Only allow trusted code to log.

threatRules.Name: Insufficient auditiing
threatRules.Description: Does the log capture enough data to understand what happened in the past? Do your logs capture enough data to understand an incident after the fact? Is such capture lightweight enough to be left on all the time? Do you have enough data to deal with repudiation claims? Make sure you log sufficient and appropriate data to handle a repudiation claims. You might want to talk to an audit expert as well as a privacy expert about your choice of data.

threatRules.Name: Potential data repudiation
threatRules.Description: The receiver claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

threatRules.Name: External entity potentially denies receiving data
threatRules.Description: The receiver claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

threatRules.Name: Data store denies potentially writing data
threatRules.Description: The receiver claims that it did not write data received from an entity on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

threatRules.Name: Authorization bypass
threatRules.Description: Custom authentication schemes are susceptible to common weaknesses such as weak credential change management, credential equivalence, easily guessable credentials, null credentials, downgrade authentication or a weak credential change management system. Consider the impact and potential mitigations for your custom authentication scheme.

threatRules.Name: Data store inaccessible
threatRules.Description: An external agent prevents access to a data store on the other side of the trust boundary.

threatRules.Name: Processing of sensitive data
threatRules.Description: Personal information such as talks, coughs, etc. is exposed and processed by an external system

threatRules.Name: Exposure of sensitive data
threatRules.Description: The loudspeaker discloses sensitive information in the public

threatRules.Name: Risk of explosion
threatRules.Description: The battery may explode

threatRules.Name: Weak cryptographic algorithms
threatRules.Description: Some Bluetooth versions use weak cryptographic algorithms

threatRules.Name: User unawareness of data collection
threatRules.Description: Personal information such as talks, coughs, etc. is exposed and processed by an external system

threatRules.Name: Full-scale outage
threatRules.Description: A full-scale outage may cause the solution to be unavailable for its users. This may be caused by natural events but also by a malicious actor.

threatRules.Name: No safety impact assessment
threatRules.Description: Evaluate the safety impacts of an IoT system, log all safety risks, prioritize the risks, and implement mitigations for each risk. Incorporate device and environmental controls to enforce safety requirements, as necessary

threatRules.Name: Certificates with long lifetime
threatRules.Description: Device certificates may be used without expiration. In this case, short-term operational certificates should be established.

threatRules.Name: No supply chain risk management program
Full-scale outage
threatRules.Description: A full-scale outage may cause the solution to be unavailable for its users. This may be caused by natural events but also by a malicious actor.

threatRules.Name: Missing time synchronization
threatRules.Description: A synchronized system time is necessary to correctly create and subsequently analyze logs.

threatRules.Name: Collision attack
threatRules.Description: Attackers who can send a series of packets or messages may be able to overlap data. For example, packet 1 may be 100 bytes starting at offset 0. Packet 2 may be 100 bytes starting at offset 25. Packet 2 will overwrite 75 bytes of packet 1. Ensure you reassemble data before filtering it, and ensure you explicitly handle these sorts of cases.

threatRules.Name: JSON processing
threatRules.Description: If a dataflow contains JSON, JSON processing and hijacking threats may be exploited.

threatRules.Name: Tag cloning
threatRules.Description: A cloned tag may enable access to sensitive data or restricted areas

threatRules.Name: Tag tracking
threatRules.Description: Tracking a tag by its unique identifier allows, for example, to create a movement profile

threatRules.Name: Tag inventorying
threatRules.Description: Tags with an EPC are vulnerable to inventory attacks. For example, medical devices such as pacemakers can be used to draw conclusions about the health of individuals.

threatRules.Name: Sending data to spoofed data store
threatRules.Description: Process has outbound data flow to data store. E.g., database is spoofed, process writes to wrong place. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-1)

threatRules.Name: Sending confidential data to data store
threatRules.Description: Process has outbound data flow to data store. E.g. process writes information to data store which should not be there. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-1)

threatRules.Name: Sending data to spoofed process
threatRules.Description: Process sends output to another process. E.g., Process2 is spoofed, Process1 writes to wrong place. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-2)

threatRules.Name: Process denies receiving data
threatRules.Description: Process sends output to another process. E.g., Process2 claims not to have received data from Process1.  (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-2)

threatRules.Name: Sending confidential data to process
threatRules.Description: Process sends output to another process. E.g., Process2 is not authorized to receive data. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-2)

threatRules.Name: Sending data to spoofed log. external entity
threatRules.Description: Process sends output to log. external entity. E.g., external entity is spoofed. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-3)

threatRules.Name: External entity denies receiving data
threatRules.Description: Process sends output to log. external entity. E.g., browser disclaims and doesn't acknowledge the output. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-3)

threatRules.Name: Sending confidential data to log. external entity
threatRules.Description: Process sends output to log. external entity. E.g., ext. entity gets data it's not authorized to get. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-3)

threatRules.Name: Phy. external entity denies receiving data
threatRules.Description: Process sends output to phy. external entity. E.g., human disclaims seeing the output. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-4)

threatRules.Name: Receiving data from spoofed data store
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from data store. E.g., database is spoofed and process reads the wrong data. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-5)

threatRules.Name: Processing corrupted data
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from data store. E.g., process is corrupted by data read from the data store. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-5)

threatRules.Name: Process denies services due to received data
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from data store. E.g., process state is corrupted by the data retrieved from the data store. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-5)

threatRules.Name: Receiving data leads to code execution
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from data store. E.g., process internal state is corrupted based on data read from the data store, leading to code execution.  (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-5)

threatRules.Name: Receiving data from spoofed process
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from another process. E.g., Process1 believes it's getting data from Process2. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-6)

threatRules.Name: Process denies receiving data
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from another process. E.g., Process1 denies getting data from Process2. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-6)

threatRules.Name: Process denies services
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from another process. E.g., Process1 crashes due to interaction with Process2. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-6)

threatRules.Name: Receiving data leads to code execution
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from another process. E.g., Process2 passes data or args that allow it to change flow of execution of Process1. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-6)

threatRules.Name: Receiving data from spoofed external entity
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from external entity. E.g., Process believes it's getting data from the ext. entity, when it fact it's a random attacker. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-7)

threatRules.Name: Process denies services
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from external entity. E.g., process crashes due to ext. entity interaction. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-7)

threatRules.Name: Receiving data leads to code execution
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from external entity. E.g., ext. entity passes data or args that allow it to change flow of execution of process. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-7)

threatRules.Name: Tampering with data flow
threatRules.Description: Data flow crosses trust boundary. E.g., data flow is modified by MITM attack. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-8)

threatRules.Name: Data flow sniffing
threatRules.Description: Data flow crosses trust boundary. E.g., the contents of the data flow are sniffed on the wire. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-8)

threatRules.Name: Denial of service
threatRules.Description: Data flow crosses trust boundary. E.g., the data flow is interrupted by an ext. entity, e.g. messing with TCP sequence numbers. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-8)

threatRules.Name: Corrupting the data store
threatRules.Description: Process has outbound data flow to data store. E.g., data store is corrupted. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-9)

threatRules.Name: Data store reveals information
threatRules.Description: Process has outbound data flow to data store. E.g., data store reveals information. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-9)

threatRules.Name: Process denies writing data
threatRules.Description: Process has outbound data flow to data store. E.g., process claims not to have written to data store. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-9)

threatRules.Name: Data store cannot be written to
threatRules.Description: Process has outbound data flow to data store. E.g., data store cannot be written to. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-9)

threatRules.Name: Process denies reading data
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from data store. E.g., process claims not to have read from data store. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-10)

threatRules.Name: Data store reveals information
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from data store. E.g., data store discloses information. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-10)

threatRules.Name: Data store cannot be read from
threatRules.Description: Process has inbound data flow from data store. E.g., data store cannot be read from. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-10)

threatRules.Name: External entity is spoofed
threatRules.Description: Ext. entity passes input to process. E.g., process is confused by the identify of the ext. entity. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-11)

threatRules.Name: Process denies receiving data
threatRules.Description: Ext. entity passes input to process. E.g., process claims not to have received data. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-11)

threatRules.Name: Process is spoofed
threatRules.Description: Ext. entity gets input from process. E.g., ext. entity is confused about the identify of the process. (see Threat modeling - designing for security: Table 3-10-11)

MitigationTips.Name: Remove interface
MitigationTips.Description: Any interface used for administration or test purposes during development should be removed from a production device, disabled or made physically inaccessible.

MitigationTips.Name: Disable interface
MitigationTips.Description: All test access points on production units must be disabled or locked, for example by blowing on-chip fuses to disable JTAG.

MitigationTips.Name: Enable access control
MitigationTips.Description: If a production device must have an administration port, ensure it has effective access controls, e.g. strong credential management, restricted ports, secure protocols etc.

MitigationTips.Name: PCB design
MitigationTips.Description: Make the device circuitry physically inaccessible to tampering, e.g. epoxy chips to circuit board, resin encapsulation, hiding data and address lines under these components etc.

MitigationTips.Name: Protective casing
MitigationTips.Description: Provide secure protective casing and mounting options for deployment of devices in exposed locations.

MitigationTips.Name: Tamper evident packaging
MitigationTips.Description: To identify and deter access within the supply chain, consider making the device and packaging “tamper evident”.

MitigationTips.Name: Active masking
MitigationTips.Description: For high-security deployments, consider design measures such as active masking or shielding to protect against side-channel attacks.

MitigationTips.Name: Mutual authentication
MitigationTips.Description: Use strong mutual authentication to ensure the authenticity of both endpoints.

MitigationTips.Name: Signed certificates
MitigationTips.Description: Validate the authenticity of public keys by their certificates. Validate the entire certificate chain.

MitigationTips.Name: Use TLS
MitigationTips.Description: Use the latest version of TLS and include only strong cipher suits.

MitigationTips.Name: Lightweight cryptography
MitigationTips.Description: In case TLS is not possible due to performance issues, choose an adequate lightweight cryptography algorithm.

MitigationTips.Name: Ensure integrity
MitigationTips.Description: If no sensitive data are transmitted and performance is a bottle neck, ensure at least the integrity of messages using a message authentication code (MAC).

MitigationTips.Name: Ensure replay protection
MitigationTips.Description: Ensure that it is not possible for a captured and resend package to be treated as legitimate.

MitigationTips.Name: Certificate pinning
MitigationTips.Description: https://owasp.org/www-community/controls/Certificate_and_Public_Key_Pinning

MitigationTips.Name: Check properties
MitigationTips.Description: Check all relevant certificate properties such as hostname

controls.Name: True random number generator
controls.Description: The generation of true random numbers is essential for many cryptographic operations. However, many pseudo-random number generators (PRNGs) are not cryptographically secure.

MitigationTips.Name: Use hardware TRNG
MitigationTips.Description: Many modern microcontroller ship with a true random number generator (TRNG). As this entropy source may be slow, it may be necessary to combine the TRNG with a cryptographically secure PRNG (CSPRNG).

MitigationTips.Name: Use different entropy sources
MitigationTips.Description: Try to collect entropy from different sources, e.g. network traffic, human interaction, etc.

MitigationTips.Name: Test the entropy
MitigationTips.Description: Test the generated entropy according to NIST SP 800-90 and SP 800-22, for example.

controls.Name: Strong block cipher mode
controls.Description: Review the latest recommendations from organizations such as NIST.

MitigationTips.Name: Use authenticated encryption
MitigationTips.Description: Modes for authenticated encryption (AE) ensure confidentiality as well as integrity. Plaintext data (e.g. in headers) can also be protected against manipulation when using a AE with associated data (AEAD).

controls.Name: Use IV and Nonce only once
controls.Description: Use an initialization vector (IV) or nonce (number used only once) only once.

MitigationTips.Name: Generate the IV using a CSPRNG
MitigationTips.Description: While it is legit to use a counter (1, 2, 3, ...), it is more practical to use a random number (generated by a cryptographically secure pseudo random number generator, CSPRNG). As IVs often have 96 bits or more, it is improbable that a number is generated twice with a CSPRNG

MitigationTips.Name: Use hash with salt
MitigationTips.Description: Do not store the password in plain text. Store the output of a cryptographic hash function. Before hashing the password, combine it with a unique, random salt (random bit string that can be treated as public) --> store hash(password | salt), for example.

MitigationTips.Name: Use password hashing algorithm
MitigationTips.Description: Not all cryptographic hash algorithms are suitable for hashing, as they are too fast, e.g. SHA2. Use a password hashing algorithm such as bcrypt or argon2.

MitigationTips.Name: Separate storage
MitigationTips.Description: Store logs in a separate partition or memory chip.

MitigationTips.Name: Central log backup
MitigationTips.Description: Send logs to a central backup storage

MitigationTips.Name: Restrict access
MitigationTips.Description: Restrict access to log files

MitigationTips.Name: Cryptographically protect logs
MitigationTips.Description: Ensure confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity of log files

MitigationTips.Name: Do's
MitigationTips.Description: Log: login, logout, authentication attempt, inactivity, password change, configuration change, privilege change, failures and errors, network activity, ....

MitigationTips.Name: Don'ts
MitigationTips.Description:
Don't log: passwords
Avoid: personal identifiable information (PII)

MitigationTips.Name: Evaluate logs
MitigationTips.Description: Monitor and evaluate the logs files for anomalies

MitigationTips.Name: Ensure availability
MitigationTips.Description: Attackers may attack log files in order to exhaust disk space or to overwrite them. Another goal could be to decrease the application performance.

controls.Name: OPC UA secure configuration
controls.Description: See Practical Security Recommendations for building OPC UA Applications by OPC Fundation

MitigationTips.Name: User authentication
MitigationTips.Description: The possibility of logging in with the identifier ‘anonymous’ should be used only for accessing non-critical UA server resources as it does not provide any protection

MitigationTips.Name: Security mode
MitigationTips.Description: The SecurityMode should be ‘Sign’ or ‘SignAndEncrypt’

MitigationTips.Name: Cryptographic algorithms
MitigationTips.Description: At a minimum, the SecurityPolicy ‘Basic256Sha256’ should be chosen

MitigationTips.Name: Use certificates
MitigationTips.Description: Don’t accept connections which do not provide trusted certificates

MitigationTips.Name: Certificate and private key storage
MitigationTips.Description: Never store private keys or the corresponding certificate files (.pfx/p12) on an unencrypted file system

MitigationTips.Name: Managing and maintaining certificates
MitigationTips.Description: Use certificate trust lists and certificate revocation lists to manage valid certificates

MitigationTips.Name: Define access control lists for topcis
Use MQTT over TLS
MitigationTips.Description: Use MQTT over TLS on port 8883

MitigationTips.Name: Define maximum message size
MitigationTips.Description: MQTT defines a maximum message size of 256MB. In most MQTT deployment scenarios, messages are often smaller than a kilobyte. If you are familiar with your usage scenario and you know the maximum message size that can occur, it makes sense to decrease the maximum allowed message size to that limit. If no limit is set, it is possible for malicious MQTT clients to send large messages (which can result in excessive memory consumption and unneeded bandwidth usage).

controls.Name: DoS protection
controls.Description: DoS depends on the used network interfaces, protocols and operating system

MitigationTips.Name: Use challenges
MitigationTips.Description: Use challenges like CAPTCHA to filter requests by bots

MitigationTips.Name: Use intrusion detection/prevention system
MitigationTips.Description: Use a intrusion detection/prevention such as Fail2ban

controls.Name: Anti-rollback protection
controls.Description:
The goal of anti-rollback protection is to prevent downgrading of the device to an older version of its software, which has been deprecated due to security concerns.

https://developer.trustedfirmware.org/w/tf_m/design/trusted_boot/rollback_protection/

MitigationTips.Name: Security counter
MitigationTips.Description: Implement an additional security counter, independently from the firmware version, to ensure anti-rollback protection. This allows downgrades to a version without bugs, for example, but prevents downgrades to vulnerable ones.

checklistTypes.Name: IEC-62443
checklistTypes.Description: CR: Component requirement, SAR: Software application requirement, EDR: Embedded device requirement, HDR: Host device requirement, NDR: Network device requirement

Levels.Name: Security Level 1
Levels.Description: Prevent the unauthorized disclosure of information via eavesdropping or causal exposure

Levels.Name: Security Level 2
Levels.Description: Prevent the unauthorized disclosure of information to an entity actively searching for it using simple means with low resources, generic skills and low motivation

Levels.Name: Security Level 3
Levels.Description: Prevent the unauthorized disclosure of information to an entity actively searching for it using sophisticated means with moderate resources, IACS specific skills and moderate motivation

Levels.Name: Security Level 4
Levels.Description: Prevent the unauthorized disclosure of information to an entity actively searching for it using sophisticated means with extended resources, IACS specific skills and high motivation
